Lori_McKenna:
{{short description|American musician}} {{Distinguish|Loreena McKennitt}} {{BLP sources|date=October 2023}}{{Infobox musical artist | name = Lori McKenna | image = LoriMcKennaNewBedfordSummerfest2006 (cropped).jpg | caption = McKenna in 2006 | birth_name = Lorraine Giroux | birth_date = {{birth date and age |1968|12|22}}{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/lori-mckenna-mn0000830890/biography|title=Lori McKenna biography|work=Allmusic|access-date=19 May 2018}} | birth_place = [[Stoughton, Massachusetts]], U.S. | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Country music|Country]] * [[Folk music|folk]] * [[Americana (music)|Americana]] }} | occupation = Singer-songwriter | instrument = {{flatlist| * Vocals * guitar }} | years_active = 1998–present | label = {{flatlist| * [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]] * [[Signature Sounds Recordings|Signature Sounds]] * [[Universal Music Publishing Group|Universal]] * Creative Nation }} | website = {{URL|lorimckenna.com}} }} '''Lorraine McKenna''' ({{née}} '''Giroux''';{{Cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/magazine/2012/03/11/lori-mckenna-writing-her-heart-out/zxXbmVKZmSzEK2foxB9hrO/story.html|title=Stoughton's Lori McKenna is Writing her Heart Out|last=Helman|first=Scott|date=March 11, 2012|website=Boston Globe}} born December 22, 1968) is an American [[Folk music|folk]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], and [[country music]] singer-songwriter. In [[58th Annual Grammy Awards|2016]], she was nominated for the [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year]] and won [[Grammy Award for Best Country Song|Best Country Song]] for co-writing the hit single "[[Girl Crush]]" performed by [[Little Big Town]].{{Cite web|url=http://winchester.wickedlocal.com/entertainment/20160216/stoughtons-lori-mckenna-wins-grammy-award/1|title=Stoughton's Lori McKenna Wins Grammy Award|last=Barbuto|first=Dana|date=February 16, 2016|website=Wicked Local - Winchester Star}} In 2017, she again won [[Grammy Award for Best Country Song|Best Country Song]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards]] for writing "[[Humble and Kind]]" performed by [[Tim McGraw]].{{Cite web|url=http://people.com/country/lori-mckenna-tim-mcgraw-humble-and-kind/|title=Watch 'Humble & Kind' Songwriter Lori McKenna Sing the CMA-Winning Tim McGraw Hit She Wrote|last=Finan|first=Eileen|date=November 2, 2016|website=People.com}} McKenna along with [[Lady Gaga]], [[Natalie Hemby]] and [[Hillary Lindsey]] wrote the second single off the soundtrack to the 2018 film ''[[A Star Is Born (2018 film)|A Star Is Born]]'' called "[[Always Remember Us This Way]].” McKenna performed backing vocals along with Lindsey and Hemby, and the song received a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] at the [[62nd Annual Grammy Awards]]. ==Early and personal life== McKenna was born and raised in [[Stoughton, Massachusetts]], where she still lives today.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/lori-mckenna-a-yankee-at-home-in-country-musics-capital/|title=Lori McKenna, a Yankee at Home in Country Music's Capital|author=|date=February 12, 2017|website=CBS News}} Her mother died when she was seven years old, a theme often touched on in her music. She met her husband, Gene McKenna, in third grade and married him at age 19. She has five children and has been married for more than 30 years. McKenna first started writing lullabies to her children. Her brother, who first introduced her to the guitar, encouraged her to attend an open-mic night at the Old Vienna Kaffeehause in [[Westborough, Massachusetts]] in 1996. The organizer heard her play and encouraged her to come back, becoming her informal manager and booking shows for her around Boston. ==Career== McKenna was managed by Gabriel Unger from 2000 to 2004. During this time, she released her first four albums under [[Signature Sounds Recordings|Signature Sounds]] and developed a folk music fan base in the Northeast.{{Cite web|url=http://nodepression.com/article/lori-mckenna-dreams-everyday-housewife|title=Lori McKenna: Dreams of an Everyday Housewife|last=Gleason|first=Holly|date=August 31, 2007|website=No Depression: The Journal of Roots Music|access-date=August 20, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180820234944/http://nodepression.com/article/lori-mckenna-dreams-everyday-housewife|archive-date=August 20, 2018|url-status=dead}} She won awards at the [[Boston Music Awards]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.bostonmusicawards07.com/|title=Boston Music Awards 07|website=www.bostonmusicawards07.com|access-date=2018-08-20}} and performed at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.gettyimages.be/gebeurtenis/sundance-film-festival-ascap-music-cafe-with-anna-nalick-lori-mckenna-los-pinguos-suzanne-vega-and-ricki-lee-jones-107657413#olivia-arciero-during-2005-sundance-film-festival-ascap-music-cafe-picture-id115856768|title=2005 Sundance Film Festival - ASCAP Music Cafe with Anna Nalick, Lori McKenna, Los Pinguos, Suzanne Vega and Ricki Lee Jones|work=Getty Images|access-date=2018-08-20|language=nl}} In 2004, singer-songwriter [[Mary Gauthier]] introduced McKenna's album ''[[Bittertown]]'' to her Nashville friends. Upon hearing it, [[Faith Hill]] stalled her completed 2005 record ''[[Fireflies (Faith Hill album)|Fireflies]]'' to replace tracks with covers of McKenna's songs. Hill and husband [[Tim McGraw]] became McKenna's champions and asked her to tour with them in 2006.{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-songwriter-lori-mckenna-on-new-album-and-hits-for-others-20161020-snap-story.html|title=Lori McKenna Stays Humble about Success, Nominations|last=Rodman|first=Sarah|date=September 19, 2016|newspaper=LA Times}} Hill took McKenna to perform with her on the ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show|Oprah Winfrey Show]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://country1025.com/2016/02/get-to-know-the-girl-behind-girl-crush-lori-mckenna-humbleandkind/|title=Get to Know: The Hometown Girl behind "Girl Crush," Lori McKenna|last=Kruse|first=Carolyn|date=February 6, 2016|website=Country 102.5|access-date=August 20, 2018|archive-date=August 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180821093751/https://country1025.com/2016/02/get-to-know-the-girl-behind-girl-crush-lori-mckenna-humbleandkind/|url-status=dead}} McGraw helped bring McKenna to [[Warner Bros. Nashville]] in 2007 and produced her album ''Unglamorous.'' Following the lackluster sales, she parted ways with Warner Bros. She then signed with [[Universal Music Group|Universal Music Group Publishing]] in 2009 and independently released her next album ''Lorraine'' in 2011. Since then, McKenna has become "one of the industry’s most in-demand songwriters."{{Cite web|url=http://pac.adelphi.edu/au_event/three-women-and-the-truth-mary-gauthier-lori-mckenna-and-gretchen-peters/|title=Three Women and the Truth|author=|website=Adelphi University Performing Arts Center|date=12 June 2023 }} She has written songs for artists including [[Sara Evans]], [[Reba McEntire]], [[Tim McGraw]], [[Carrie Underwood]], and [[Keith Urban]]. She wrote 10 songs that made it to the Billboard Hot Country list, including [[Hunter Hayes]]' "[[I Want Crazy]]", Faith Hill's "[[Stealing Kisses]]", Tim McGraw's "[[Humble and Kind]]"; and [[Little Big Town]]'s "Your Side of the Bed", "Sober", and "Girl Crush."{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7332956/lori-mckenna-country-chart-hits-solo-songwriters|title=Lori McKenna Brings the Solo Songwriter Back to No. 1 on Hot Country Songs|last=Trust|first=Gary|date=April 12, 2016|magazine=Billboard}} McKenna writes solo and co-writes with songwriters [[Hillary Lindsey|Hillary Lindsay]] and [[Liz Rose]]. The group wrote the song "[[Girl Crush]]", and it became a hit for the band [[Little Big Town]]. The song received Grammy nominations for both [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Country Song|Best Country Song]], winning the latter in 2016. The song was nominated for Song of the Year Song at the [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], and won Song of the Year at the [[Country Music Association Awards]]. McKenna won another Grammy the next year for Best Country Song for "Humble and Kind" by Tim McGraw.{{Cite web|url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/02/12/grammys-lori-mckenna-wins-best-country-song/97829604/|title=Grammys: Lori McKenna Wins Best Country Song|last=Thanki|first=Juli|date=February 12, 2017|website=Tennessean}} McKenna wrote the song as "lullaby, guidebook, and tribute" to her five children. The song was named Song of the Year at the 2016 [[Country Music Association Awards|CMA Awards]] and won favorite country song at the [[American Music Awards]] the same year. In 2017, "Humble and Kind" was nominated for Song of the Year and Single Record of the Year at the [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM Awards]]. McKenna was named Songwriter of the Year at the ACM's that same year. McKenna has received critical acclaim for her album ''The Bird and the Rifle''. The album was produced by [[Dave Cobb]] and nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album|Best Americana Album]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards|59th annual Grammy Awards]], and the single "Wreck You" was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Song|Best American Roots Song]] and [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Performance|Best American Roots Performance]]. McKenna was nominated for the 2017 [[American Music Award for Artist of the Year|Americana Music Awards Artist of the Year]]. Her 10th studio album, ''The Tree'', was produced by [[Dave Cobb]] and released in summer 2018 through Thirty Tiger Records.{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/07/12/627245736/first-listen-lori-mckenna-the-tree|title=Lori McKenna's 'The Tree' Documents What Happens Between Life|last=McKenna|first=Britney|date=July 12, 2018|website=NPR}} In 2015, McKenna was signed to a management and publishing deal with Creative Nation, a Nashville-based company owned and operated by songwriter Luke Laird and his wife Beth. On September 25, 2018, McKenna signed a publishing deal with Creative Nation for a three-year deal. In 2020, McKenna released her eleventh album, ''[[The Balladeer (album)|The Balladeer]]'', through CN Records and [[Thirty Tigers]]. Music critic [[Robert Christgau]] hailed it as "the most consistently top-notch album of her late-blooming career".{{cite web|last=Christgau|first=Robert|author-link=Robert Christgau|date=August 12, 2020|url=https://robertchristgau.substack.com/p/consumer-guide-august-2020|title=Consumer Guide: August, 2020|work=And It Don't Stop|publisher=[[Substack]]|access-date=August 12, 2020|url-access=subscription}} In 2020, McKenna co-wrote "[[A Beautiful Noise]]" with 7 other female writers - [[Alicia Keys]], [[Brandi Carlile]], [[Brandy Clark]], [[Hillary Lindsey]], [[Ruby Amanfu]], [[Hailey Whitters]] and [[Linda Perry]] - and the song was performed by [[Alicia Keys]] and [[Brandi Carlile]] with the purpose of inspiring American voters to vote in the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 Presidential Election.]]{{Cite web|date=2020-10-30|title=Watch Alicia Keys and Brandi Carlile premiere new song 'A Beautiful Noise' {{!}} NME|url=https://www.nme.com/en_asia/news/music/watch-alicia-keys-and-brandi-carlile-premiere-new-song-a-beautiful-noise-2805132|access-date=2020-12-27|website=NME {{!}} Music, Film, TV, Gaming & Pop Culture News|language=en}} In 2021, singer-songwriter [[Taylor Swift]] released her second re-recorded album ''[[Red (Taylor's Version)]]'', including a song called "[[I Bet You Think About Me]]" featuring [[Chris Stapleton]].
